_exec_summary.SummaryText:
- 1 -

                              Last printed 6/11/2004 3:18 PM

                  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FEDERAL

                    RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

                  E&J GALLO WINERY - FRESNO

                          JUNE 2004





     The E & J Gallo Fresno Winery is located at 5610 East

Olive Avenue in Fresno, California.  The facility crushes

grapes in order to produce wine, distilled spirits, and

juice for concentrate.  These products are stored prior to

shipment to other Gallo facilities for further processing

and distribution.



     The facility operates anhydrous ammonia refrigeration

systems to provide product cooling.  Refrigeration systems

have storage vessels (receivers) sized to contain all the

liquid ammonia in the system, with additional capacity for

thermal expansion.



     The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop heat

transfer system.  Ammonia moves through the system due to

pressure differences produced by the compressors.  A brief

description of the ammonia refrigeration cycle follows:



refrigeration cycle follows:



  1.   The receiver vessel stores liquid ammonia under

       pressure.  High pressure liquid ammonia flows from the

       receiver through liquid lines to the expansion valve, which

       partitions the pressure and temperature.  Liquid ammonia at

       reduced pressure and temperature is then piped in to the

       chiller shell.

2.   Product is circulated through sealed stainless steel

tubing within the chiller shell.  Heat from the warm product

transfers through the tubing walls to the cooler

refrigerant, causing liquid refrigerant to boil off as low

pressure vapor.  The rate of vaporization, and thereby the

cooling of product, is determined by the amount of pressure

in the chiller as controlled by a back pressure regulator,

and suction from the compressors.

3.   The compressors draw the low pressure vapor from the

chiller, compress it into to high

pressure vapor, and

discharge it to the evaporative condenser (cooling tower).

4.   In the evaporative condenser, ammonia vapor flows

through tubing which is sprayed with water and located

within fan driven air flow to promote cooling.  The ammonia

vapor transfers heat through the tubing walls to the cooling

water.  The ammonia condenses back to a liquid which drains

by gravity to the receiver vessel.



     In addition to ammonia refrigeration systems, the

facility uses anhydrous ammonia to adjust the pH of process

water being discharged to the Fresno POTW.

     .

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY FOR RMP COVERED PROCESSES





     The following statements apply to the listed regulated

substances held in processes covered by the Federal Risk

Management Program.





Ammonia



     In the five year period prio

r to this submission, the E

& J Gallo Winery has experienced no ammonia incidents

resulting in injury to employees or injury or evacuation of

the public.  However, there were six incidents during which

ammonia vapor was released from Federal RMP Processes:



  1.   The first incident took place on June 28, 1999.

     Approximately 121 pounds of ammonia were released to the

     atmosphere from a broken one half inch nipple fitting on a

     gauge going into tank 6524.



  2.   The second incident took place on November 29, 1999.

     An unknown amount of ammonia was released to the atmosphere

     from a failed compressor seal.



  3.   The third incident took place on July 30, 2001.

     Approximately 150 pounds of ammonia were released to the

     atmosphere from unknown equipment.



  4.   The fourth incident took place on April 24, 2002.

     Approximately 74 pounds of ammonia were released to the

     atmosphere from unknown equipment.



  5.   The fifth incident took place on June 21, 2002.  An

     unknown amount of ammonia was released from an evaporator

     hot well.



  6.   The sixth incident took place on June 3, 2003.

     Approximately 100-500 pounds of ammonia were released to the

     atmosphere from a safety release valve at tower 14.





     Notifications were made to the Fresno County Department

of Health Services during all seven incidents.  No clean up

was necessary for any incident.



Mayra, please include the incidents that I pulled from OES.

This would be for two ammonia releases.  Rod:  please point

Myra in the direction of the binder of the release reports.

Following these incidents, an in-house team conducted an

investigation and made several recommendations.  Corrective

actions to prevent future similar incidents are in progress.







TOXIC WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

TOXIC ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS



Ammonia



     An alternative release scenario would involve damage to

liquid ammonia piping at a chiller due to contact from

motorized equipment operating in the area.  If damage was

sufficient to cause a failure, it could occur at a flange

due to bolt failure, and result in a 1 inch square opening.

The release of liquid ammonia from the opening could be

expelled in to the air and onto the surrounding surfaces.







ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



     The E & J Gallo Winery employs RETA- trainedcertified

refrigeration mechanics, supported by engineering staff.

The refrigeration system is maintained through thea

scheduled  implementation of a scheduled preventative

maintenance program based upon standard industry practices.

what maintenance program?  Can we talk specifics?  , and

many years of practical experience.  Employees required to

operate ammonia refrigeration equipment receive training

specific to their assigned duties.





and hold the appropriate RETA certifications (is this a

correct statement - Rod?).





EMERGENCY RESPONSE



     In the event of a reportable chemical release,

notifications will be made to the appropriate agencies

including the Fresno County Department of Health Services,

Health Services Agency, the State Office of Emergency

Services (as directed by the Fresno County CUPA), and the

Federal Nnational Response Center (as appropriate)..



     Gallo management and members of the in-house emergency

response team willould respond to the emergency site, and

work with public emergency response personnel in mitigating

the problem.







MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



     The Management of Change Procedure will require

evaluation of new construction and modifications to existing

ammonia systems to determine the likelihood of an effect on

ammonia safety.  Changes expected to have a significant

safety effect on quantity, systems, or procedures

will be

referred to the appropriate Risk Management Program team for

further study.







COMPLIANCE AUDITS



     E & J Gallo Winery will perform  an annual Risk

Management Program compliance audits.  .  The specific items

in the Risk Management Plan will be re-examined and

compliance documented.  The team reviewing these systems

will consist of personnel from Engineering, Instrumentation,

Maintenance, and Operations.







PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



     Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOPS) of the ammonia

systems were conducted in May 2004.  As a result of the

study, numerous improvements have been identified.  A multi-

month process hazard analysis (PHA) started in April 2004

has identified approximately 72 recommendations.  The

recommendations will be followed by a Risk Management

Program/Process Safety Management steering committee which

includes the senior managers on site.  This steering

committee will assign ownership of all recommendations and

will meet on a quarterly basis to evaluate progress.



     These recommendations address such subjects as improved

training, standard operating procedures, the value and

feasibility of non-destructive testing, increased vehicle

barricading, improved alarm and control systems, audits,

checklists, upgraded hardware, improved interlocks,

management of change, use of personal protective equipment,

etc.







PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



     The E & J Gallo Winery performed process hazard

analyses of the ammonia systems. The latest process hazard

analysis (PHA) was started April 26th, 2004.  Using "PHA Pro

6" software by Dyadem Corporation, five employees met two-

three times per week for several hours per session to review

the ammonia systems.  These meetings have been conducted for

the past two months and will continue through July 2004.



     The five member team conducting the PHAs included a

refrigeration mechanic, refrigeration operator/Team Leader,

a Corporate Safety

and Health Manager extensively trained in

PHA methodology and refrigeration systems, a site Safety and

Health Specialist, and the site Environmental

Coordinator/Team Leader.  In total, approximately 200 man-

hours have been spent on the ammonia PHAs when they are

completed.



     After the PHAs are completed, the approximately 72

recommendations will be followed up by a Risk Management

Program/Process Safety Management steering committee which

includes the senior managers on site.  This steering

committee will assign ownership of all recommendations and

will meet on a quarterly basis to evaluate progress.



     Process flow diagrams were used to develop the process

sections used to evaluate the systems.





Ammonia Refrigeration         Plant Ammonia Systems

A   Receivers, tanks, vessels M   Plant ammonia receiver,

                              piping, valves

B   Liquid manifolds and      N   Distillery scrubbing

valves                        system

C   Chiller                   O   Ion exchange wastewater

                              pH control system

D   Float Column              P   Pumps

E   Back pressure regulator   X   Ammonium hydroxide system

F   Compressors               Y   Wastewater sump pH

                              control system

G   Separators                Z   Evaporator hot well

H   Condenser                 

I     Piping and tubing       

J    Electrical Systems       

                              



     The following parameters were selected for each process

section:



a.   Flow                     d.   Quantity/Level

b.   Pressure                 e.   Material composition

c.   Temperature              





     Additional parameters were considered where

appropriate, including:

  

h.   Electrical systems

l.     Operational considerations





The following guidewords were applied to the parameters as

appropriate:



1.   No                       10.   Drop

2.   Less                     11.   As w

ell as

4.   Restricted               13.   Interrupted

8.   Suction                  17.   Ruptured

9.   Higher                   18.   Intermittent





     The combination of parameters and guidewords describe a

possible deviation.  The HAZOPS team analyzed these

deviations to determine possible causes, consequences,

probability, severity, and safeguards.  It should be noted

that many combinations reflect normal operating conditions,

or conditions that present little or no risk.



     In addition, the HAZOPS team plans to tour the facility

to inspect areas involved in the use or storage of these

materials. Consideration will be given to external factors

such as the location of traffic, personnel, equipment, or

other processes in the vicinity, fire hazards, and weather.



     Recommendations have been made in response to concerns

raised during the HAZOPS process.  The meeting minutes,

agendas, and records of the HAZOP studies are maintained in

the main office of the Winery.
